episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:05.157
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.157 --> 00:00:06.625
Hello and thank you for watching DevProTV.

3
00:00:06.625 --> 00:00:09.553
We're talking with Justin Dennison
about this course,

4
00:00:09.553 --> 00:00:11.840
applied fundamentals, guess the number.

5
00:00:11.840 --> 00:00:13.690
Justin, can you tell us what
the course is all about?

6
00:00:13.690 --> 00:00:17.265
>> So the course is actually to take some
of our Python knowledge that we've built

7
00:00:17.265 --> 00:00:18.957
up in the previous courses thus far.

8
00:00:18.957 --> 00:00:23.980
And kind of apply those, applied
fundamentals, who would have thought?

9
00:00:23.980 --> 00:00:28.208
To create, guess the number,
a very simple game where the object is,

10
00:00:28.208 --> 00:00:30.588
the computer selects a random number.

11
00:00:30.588 --> 00:00:33.176
And then you go, is it that,
is it that, is it that?

12
00:00:33.176 --> 00:00:37.645
Now, I know it doesn't, hey, listen,
it's not Halo, it's not Fallout,

13
00:00:37.645 --> 00:00:38.748
you're correct.

14
00:00:38.748 --> 00:00:43.562
But it does encapsulate a great deal of
things that we have learnt up until this

15
00:00:43.562 --> 00:00:44.460
point.

16
00:00:44.460 --> 00:00:46.678
And so
that's the ultimate goal of this course.

17
00:00:46.678 --> 00:00:48.313
>> Awesome, now,
who's the show targeted towards?

18
00:00:48.313 --> 00:00:50.856
>> This show is targeted to someone who,
hey,

19
00:00:50.856 --> 00:00:53.483
you've come through our previous courses.

20
00:00:53.483 --> 00:00:57.252
Introduction to Python, programming
fundamentals, those type of courses,

21
00:00:57.252 --> 00:00:59.068
where you're just getting started.

22
00:00:59.068 --> 00:01:01.150
Like, all right, I have all of this
knowledge, I have this piece and

23
00:01:01.150 --> 00:01:02.670
this piece and this piece.

24
00:01:02.670 --> 00:01:06.060
How do I put these pieces together and
actually build something that maybe you

25
00:01:06.060 --> 00:01:11.180
can hand off to someone else, they can
play it, and see your programming skills.

26
00:01:11.180 --> 00:01:16.060
So it's a very kind of introductory,
maybe an essential type thing,

27
00:01:16.060 --> 00:01:18.190
a rite of passage, if you will.

28
00:01:18.190 --> 00:01:22.850
I take all of these Mega Blok bricks and
then put them together into,

29
00:01:22.850 --> 00:01:24.810
well, a guess the number game.

30
00:01:24.810 --> 00:01:27.070
>> Is there a certification available for
the course?

31
00:01:27.070 --> 00:01:29.602
>> This is not certification based,
and the reason being,

32
00:01:29.602 --> 00:01:32.252
it would be hard,
I don't even know you'd get certified.

33
00:01:32.252 --> 00:01:35.034
It'd be like, you are a certified
guess the number builder,

34
00:01:35.034 --> 00:01:36.866
[LAUGH] I don't know how that would work.

35
00:01:36.866 --> 00:01:41.400
But, in the long term, this is setting you
up to see how the pieces of a programming

36
00:01:41.400 --> 00:01:46.410
language, how your thought process kind of
comes together to build an application.

37
00:01:46.410 --> 00:01:49.807
Which, maybe that does lead to
certifications in the future, so

38
00:01:49.807 --> 00:01:53.657
think of this as a stepping stone to
getting a little better at your craft.

39
00:01:53.657 --> 00:01:56.508
>> And you already kind of touched on it,
but what topics are covered in the show?

40
00:01:56.508 --> 00:02:01.351
>> So this topic is actually gonna
look at conditions, functions, loops,

41
00:02:01.351 --> 00:02:03.625
to some extent, how a game works.

42
00:02:03.625 --> 00:02:10.030
And things like, okay, I'm printing
to the screen, I'm taking user input.

43
00:02:10.030 --> 00:02:14.490
So there's a lot of these basic
elements that you may need for

44
00:02:14.490 --> 00:02:17.390
very simple applications that
are all rolled into one.

45
00:02:17.390 --> 00:02:19.950
It is a pick and choose,

46
00:02:19.950 --> 00:02:25.080
essentially, of a lot of the topics
that we've seen in previous courses.

47
00:02:25.080 --> 00:02:28.343
>> Thanks, Justin, so if applied
fundamentals guess the number sounds like

48
00:02:28.343 --> 00:02:30.568
a course you'd be interested in,
and you should,

49
00:02:30.568 --> 00:02:33.338
make sure to see all the episodes
inside of our course library.

50
00:02:33.338 --> 00:02:36.848
And thank you for watching DevProTV,
a good dev pro is always learning.

51
00:02:36.848 --> 00:02:43.328
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne plan a simple game where a user will guess a randomly selected number. Justin thinks through the interactions, design, and considerations for creating the the game.
episodes.title: Plan the Project

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach set up the project structure to get started with the guess the number game.
episodes.title: Set Up the Project

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach add the ability to take a guess from the user.
episodes.title: Take a Guess

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach discuss that the game is not clear about the goal. Justin takes some time to adding some user instructions for playing the game.
episodes.title: Add User Instructions

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach explore that the source code organization and how the source could be reorganized. Justin takes some time to extract portions of the program to functions to increase readability.
episodes.title: Refactor to Functions

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach demonstrate how to limit the number of guesses that user has in order to have a losing state for the game.
episodes.title: Limit the Guesses

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach utilize the limitations to guesses to determine whether a user wins or loses. Justin also adds some user feedback about whether they won or lost.
episodes.title: Determine Win or Lose
